channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Spanish Opera House to Lose Crumbling Facade by Star Architect
item.description: The structural problems of Valencia’s opera house, which has been closed because of falling tiles, are the latest in the travails of Santiago Calatrava.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. & A.: Wu Wei Reflects on Reform, Now and in the 1980s
item.description: Wu Wei, a former Chinese official who in the 1980s was heavily involved in developing plans for measured political reform, says recently announced economic changes will stall without substantial changes to the political system.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Courtesy of Wu Wei and New Century Press
item.media:description: Wu Wei, right, with General Secretary Zhao Ziyang of the Communist Party, center, in 1987.

item.title: Pope Looks South in Appointing Cardinals
item.description: Pope Francis named 16 cardinals from small, poor countries like Haiti, Burkina Faso, Nicaragua and Ivory Coast, but none from the United States.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Senior Libyan Official Assassinated, First Since Qaddafi Era
item.description: A deputy cabinet minister was killed by a gunman on Saturday in the first assassination of a senior Libyan government figure since 2011.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Praise and Criticism as Sharon’s Body Lies in State
item.description: Thousands of Israelis filed past the body of former Prime Minister Ariel Sharon on Sunday, some expressing admiration for his reputation as a leader unafraid to take risks and others voicing harsh assessments.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Iran Nuclear Deal to Take Effect Jan. 20, Officials Say
item.description: In return for freezing much of Iran’s program, the United States and its negotiating partners will provide Iran with billions of dollars in relief from economic sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Protesters in Thailand Move to Shut Down Bangkok
item.description: The government mobilized the police and soldiers as anti-government protesters seeking to block next month’s elections took over major roads.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: By late Sunday, protesters had blocked a number of roads with double-decker buses and sandbags, and had diverted traffic.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: New Detail Emerges About Bo Xilai’s Downfall
item.description: A new article says John Garnaut, a prominent Australian reporter based in Beijing for the Sydney Morning Herald, was called in to act as the interpreter for Wang Lijun, the former Chongqing police chief who reported his suspicion that Bo Xilai’s wife had murdered the British businessman Neil Heywood.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Bo Guagua, left, with his father, Bo Xilai, in 2007.

item.title: Indonesia Announces Export Ban on Raw Ore
item.description: The ban on exports of unprocessed minerals has been criticized by miners who say a plan to build smelters in the country is not economically viable.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Coastal Province’s Fishing Rules Alarm U.S.
item.description: The United States reacted with dismay to new rules issued by Hainan Province in China that require foreign fishing vessels to obtain permission from the Chinese government before plying disputed sea waters that China claims.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Fishermen bustle with their wares in Hainan, where the provincial government says that foreign fishing vessels must obtain approval to enter waters it says are under its jurisdiction.

item.title: For Financier, a Final Try to Avoid U.S. Charges
item.description: Florian Homm, a German arrested after five years in hiding, will make a final appeal against extradition to the Italian justice ministry, citing ill health.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: Show Banned, French Comedian Has New One
item.description: France’s highest administrative court upheld a ban on a show by the comedian, Dieudonné M’Bala M’Bala, in Tours, days after it was also banned in Nantes.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Presidential Run Likely for Egypt’s Top General
item.description: General Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi all but explicitly linked his candidacy to this week’s referendum on a revised constitution.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A man with a copy of the proposed new Constitution at a lecture about its provisions.

item.title: 2 Far-Right Greek Lawmakers Are Accused of Criminal Activity
item.description: Giorgos Germenis and Panagiotis Iliopoulos, lawmakers from the Golden Dawn party, were ordered to be detained pending trial on charges of joining and directing a criminal organization.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Violence Replaces Rejoicing After Central African Leaders Resign
item.description: After thousands celebrated the resignations of two of the Central African Republic’s leaders, Christian militias renewed their fight with the Muslim rebels known as Seleka.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: French soldiers stood guard as looters who had been shot were treated on Saturday in Bangui, Central African Republic.

item.title: Defying Japan, Rancher Saves Fukushima’s Radioactive Cows
item.description: Angered by what he considers Japan’s efforts to sweep away the inconvenient truths of a nuclear disaster, a rancher returns to the no-man’s land near the devastated plant.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Masami Yoshizawa’s newly renamed Ranch of Hope, which is in the evacuation zone created by the 2011 disaster at Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant.

item.title: Rising Tide Is a Mystery That Sinks Island Hopes
item.description: Lago Enriquillo in the Dominican Republic, the largest lake in the Caribbean, has been rising and rising, devouring tens of thousands of acres of farmland, ranches and whatever else stands in its way.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fishermen in Lake Enriquillo among a sea of dead trees where farmers formerly reaped bountiful harvests.

item.title: In Scandal, Turkey’s Leaders May Be Losing Their Tight Grip on News Media
item.description: The Turkish government, which has frequently had journalists fired and even jailed, may be losing its grip on the news media, as a former ally turns and Internet influence abounds.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, whose government is being investigated amid allegations of corruption.

item.title: The Lede: Syria’s Conflict Told Through a Caustic Wit
item.description: “You know, when you live with shelling all the time, you just let everything go,” said the Syrian activist Razan Ghazzawi. “You have to laugh.”
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK
item.media:description: President Obama was portrayed to be a superhero whose inflatable muscles were easily popped by a pin, at a protest in Kafranbel. Many Syrian activists are critical of the United States for what they describe as its lackluster support for the country's rebel groups.

item.title: Matriarchs’ Duel for Power Threatens to Tilt Bangladesh Off Balance
item.description: A tumultuous election may mean the end of two rivals’ coexistence — and the beginning of a risky attempt at one-party rule.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Left, Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; right, Khaled Hasan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheikh Hasina, left, after elections that were boycotted by Begum Khaleda Zia and the opposition. For 20 years, control has been largely in the hands of one of the two women.

item.title: Israel and World Grapple With Sharon’s Mixed Legacy
item.description: A life and career paralleled Israel’s development, for better or worse.
item.dc:creator: By RINA CASTELNUOVO and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: A Guillotine in Storage Bears Signs of a Role in Silencing Nazis’ Critics
item.description: The Bavarian National Museum has provisionally identified a guillotine as the one the Nazis used to execute Sophie and Hans Scholl, who led the White Rose resistance to Hitler.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: ADN/Picture-Alliance, via DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Hans and Sophie Scholl were executed in 1943 for leading a student resistance against the Nazis.

item.title: France Oil Giant Is Expected to Seek Shale Gas in Britain
item.description: It would be the first major oil company explore for natural gas and oil in shale rock in that country.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED

item.title: Light-Bulb Moments for a Nonprofit
item.description: A group that creates medical technology for developing countries has found that the job goes far beyond research and design.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE LARSON
item.media:description: Krista Donaldson, center, is chief executive of D-Rev, a nonprofit group that designs medical equipment for use in developing countries and licenses it to distributors.

item.title: Ariel Sharon, 1928-2014
item.description: A cunning general who went on to hold nearly every top Israeli government post, Mr. Sharon suffered a stroke in 2006 and fell into a coma from which he never awoke.
